feed.title: The Low B Dispatch
feed.subtitle: An automated sports journalism pipeline utilizing custom Selenium scrapers and Google Gemini to provide professional-grade coverage of Toronto's DMHL.

entry.title: The Playoff Picture Clears (Mostly): A Week of Seismic Seeding Shifts

link.title: The Playoff Picture Clears (Mostly): A Week of Seismic Seeding Shifts

entry.content:
The Playoff Picture Clears (Mostly): A Week of Seismic Seeding Shifts As the regular season winds down, every point is a battle, and this week delivered the high-stakes drama we craved.

The Scramble for Seeding

With Don Cherry’s having already clinched the top spot, the real action this week was in the congested middle of the standings, as teams jostled for playoff positioning. The Monday/Wednesday Low B division is heading into playoffs hot, with the best-of-two series kicking off on February 25th.

Monday night at St. Mikes Arena, under a typical chilly Toronto February sky, we saw two crucial matchups. First up, the Flat-Earthers decisively beat 4 Lines with a 6-1 victory at 9:00 PM. Flat-Earthers, securing second place, got a multi-goal performance from Ethan Hirst (2G), with Reid Chessell (1G, 1A) and Alex Adolphe (1G, SH) adding to the offense. For 4 Lines, Riley Hanson’s late first-period goal was their lone marker. This loss keeps 4 Lines in 3rd with 18 points, but with a pivotal makeup game against these same Flat-Earthers next week, their seeding is far from set.

Immediately before that, at 8:00 PM, The Shockers and Don Cherry’s battled to a hard-fought 2-2 tie. Michael Murphy (1G, 1A) and Nik Tsatsos (1G) found the net for Don Cherry’s, while Caden Bower (1G) and Gabe Fischer-Schmidt (1G) answered for The Shockers. The cleanliness of this contest was notable, with no penalties called by Referee Evan Benwell, a rare sight in a high-intensity game. The single point moves The Shockers to 16 points, making them part of a three-way tie for 4th, 5th, and 6th.

Wednesday’s lone game at 7:00 PM saw The Sahara pull away from the Muffin Men with a 5-2 win at St. Mikes. Wes Martin was a force, notching two goals, including a power-play marker, and an assist. Wil Nenadovic also contributed with a power-play goal. For the Muffin Men, Mitchell Cianfarini and Ryan Irwin scored in the third to narrow the gap. This victory propels The Sahara (17 points) into 4th place, just ahead of The Shockers and Muffin Men (both at 16 points). The implications are immense: The Sahara currently sits in a 3rd vs 4th playoff matchup scenario, leaving The Shockers to face the formidable Flat-Earthers, and the Muffin Men to challenge Don Cherry’s in the 1st vs 6th slot.

The final regular-season makeup game next week between 4 Lines and Flat-Earthers holds the key to locking in these tight lower-bracket matchups. Every shot, every save, and every penalty will matter.

The Three Stars of the Week

1st Star: Wes Martin (The Sahara)

2 Goals, 1 Assist, 1 Power Play Goal. Martin’s offensive outburst was directly responsible for securing a crucial two points for The Sahara, propelling them up the standings and dictating potential playoff matchups.

2nd Star: Ethan Hirst (Flat-Earthers)

2 Goals. Hirst’s pair of goals helped the Flat-Earthers to a commanding win, solidifying their second-place position heading into the playoffs.

3rd Star: Michael Murphy (Don Cherry’s)

1 Goal, 1 Assist. Even in a tie, Murphy’s steady offensive contribution ensures Don Cherry’s continues to roll, maintaining their top-seed momentum.
entry.summary: As the regular season winds down, every point is a battle, and this week delivered the high-stakes drama we craved.

entry.title: Monday Night Mayhem: Cherry’s Rolls, Mid-Pack Tightens as Winter Bites

link.title: Monday Night Mayhem: Cherry’s Rolls, Mid-Pack Tightens as Winter Bites

entry.content:
The Week’s Rundown

The Monday/Wednesday Low B division kicked off the week with a clear stratification developing at the top, while the middle-of-the-pack scrap remains as tight as the goalies’ five-holes. Under a crisp, typically Canadian February sky, with temperatures hovering near freezing, pucks dropped at St. Mikes and Upper Canada College School Arena.

Don Cherry’s continued their dominant run, solidifying their top spot with a commanding 9-2 victory over the Muffin Men at St. Mikes. While Muffin Men’s Owen Burry and Charles Levy found the net, Don Cherry’s offense was relentless.

Don Cherry’s offense was a full-team effort, with Cassady Louks bagging two goals and an assist, and Nik Tsatsos adding a pair. Sean Murphy was the architect, tallying three assists.

This decisive win further cements Don Cherry’s significant lead in the standings, boasting a league-best Goal Differential of +33 and a GFA of 4.47.

The 10 PM slot at St. Mikes saw a rollicking 6-6 tie between The Sahara and the Flat-Earthers. This back-and-forth affair was a test of endurance and offensive firepower.

Kosta Likourezos of The Sahara was a force, notching a hat-trick and two assists, including the game-tying goal in the third period. For the Flat-Earthers, Anthony Pennino orchestrated much of their attack with a goal and three assists.

Meanwhile, at the Upper Canada College School Arena, The Shockers edged out 4 Lines in a tightly contested 4-3 battle. This game, played at the late 10:30 PM slot, was notably more physical. Referees Russell Nichols and Eric Beltrami were busy, calling six penalties in total, highlighting the intensity of the matchup.

The Shockers mounted a crucial third-period comeback, propelled by Caden Bower’s goal and three assists, including an assist on Nick Chong’s short-handed marker. For 4 Lines, Adam Miller put up two goals and an assist in a valiant effort.

This win brings The Shockers level on points with The Sahara, both sitting at 15 points, tightening the race for the middle seeds. The Muffin Men’s loss keeps them precariously close, only one point ahead of this surging duo.

The Three Stars of the Week

1st Star: Kosta Likourezos (The Sahara)

With 3 goals and 2 assists in The Sahara’s 6-6 draw, Likourezos was the primary offensive engine, scoring the crucial equalizer.

2nd Star: Caden Bower (The Shockers)

Bower’s 1 goal and 3 assists were instrumental in The Shockers’ 4-3 comeback win, demonstrating clutch playmaking.

3rd Star: Anthony Pennino (Flat-Earthers)

Pennino recorded 1 goal and 3 assists, consistently generating offense and keeping the Flat-Earthers in their high-scoring tie.
entry.summary: Low B's sees dominant performances and crucial mid-tier battles under a frigid Toronto sky.

entry.title: Mid-Week Mayhem: Flat-Earthers Gain Ground, 4 Lines and Muffin Men Split the Difference

link.title: Mid-Week Mayhem: Flat-Earthers Gain Ground, 4 Lines and Muffin Men Split the Difference

entry.content:
Division Recap

This week brought a familiar chill to St. Mikes Arena, but the play on the ice was anything but frozen. Don Cherry’s continued their dominant run, dispatching The Sahara 5-3 on Wednesday night. While Cherry’s secured the win, The Sahara’s Kosta Likourezos and Sam Goldstein each potted a goal and an assist, showing some spark. Koch Tsatsos led the Cherry’s attack with a pair of goals, while Dongyeon Kim added a goal and an assist.

Monday’s slate delivered both a decisive victory and a tightly contested draw. The Flat-Earthers cemented their hold on second place with a 6-3 win over The Shockers. This game was a lively affair, with Referees Evan Benwell and Russell Nichols calling seven penalties, hinting at the competitive edge. The Flat-Earthers capitalized, notably with a short-handed goal from Anthony Pennino and another from Daniel Solomos, who finished with two goals. Brandon Sanders was instrumental for the Flat-Earthers, tallying a goal and two assists. For The Shockers, Caden Bower notched a pair of goals in a losing effort.

Meanwhile, the 8 PM Monday slot saw 4 Lines and the Muffin Men battle to a 3-3 draw. Both teams traded blows, with the Muffin Men’s Aaron Barrett, Cole Singleton, and the well-known “Spare” finding the net. 4 Lines responded with goals from Thomas Mchugh, Ellis Gerussi-Turner, and Adam Miller, who also added an assist. The tie keeps 4 Lines in third but denies them two crucial points in their pursuit of the Flat-Earthers.

Three Stars of the Week

  • 1st Star: Brandon Sanders (Flat-Earthers)

    Sanders was all over the ice against The Shockers, netting a goal and adding two assists (3 points). His offensive contributions were pivotal in his team’s convincing win.

  • 2nd Star: Daniel Solomos (Flat-Earthers)

    Solomos made his presence felt with two goals against The Shockers, including a crucial shorthanded marker. Impactful plays when it counted.

  • 3rd Star: David Kim (Flat-Earthers)

    A subtle but effective performance, Kim recorded two assists and drew a penalty in his team’s victory. He demonstrated a knack for being in the middle of the action, both offensively and defensively.
entry.summary: A look at the latest from the Monday/Wednesday Low B division, where the standings saw some jostling and penalties flew in one contentious matchup.

entry.title: Shaking Up the Mid-Pack
entry.content:
The Grind

The Downtown Men’s Hockey League’s Monday/Wednesday Low B division saw some significant shifts this past week, even if not all were earned on the ice. Don Cherry’s solidified their top spot, not with a highlight-reel goal, but an “Official Forfeit” victory over 4 Lines on Monday night at St. Mikes. While a win is a win, it certainly leaves fans wanting more puck drops.

Speaking of more action, The Shockers delivered a dominant performance, shutting out The Sahara 5-0 at Upper Canada College School Arena. The late 10:30 PM start on a chilly Monday, typical of Toronto in late January, didn’t dampen their spirits.

“The Shockers scored five unanswered goals, with #3 Caden Bower contributing a goal and two assists, including a helper on the short-handed tally by #18 Gabe Fischer-Schmidt.”

This commanding win propels The Shockers into a tie with The Sahara in points (15), nudging them ahead with a superior win count.

Wednesday night, Flat-Earthers edged out the Muffin Men 4-2 at St. Mikes. It was a tight battle, with Flat-Earthers’ #5 Reid Chessell opening the scoring. Muffin Men’s #10 Charles Levy kept his team in it, potting both of their goals, showcasing a relentless effort even in defeat. The officiating was light for this contest, with only one minor penalty called against Muffin Men’s Ryan Irwin. In contrast, the Shockers-Sahara game saw a combined five minors, indicating a more physical affair overseen by referees Mark Donohoe and Eric Beltrami.

Three Stars of the Week

  • 1st Star: Caden Bower (The Shockers) – A goal and two assists (3 points) in The Shockers’ 5-0 triumph, including a primary assist on the game’s opening goal and a helper on the shorthanded marker. A truly impactful performance.
  • 2nd Star: Maxime Gagnon (The Shockers) – Also recorded a goal and two assists (3 points), rounding out The Shockers’ scoring in their decisive shutout victory.
  • 3rd Star: Charles Levy (Muffin Men) – Notched both goals for the Muffin Men against the Flat-Earthers. Despite the loss, Levy’s individual offensive output was commendable.
entry.summary: Forfeit Fallout and a Shocking Rise Define the Week in Low B

entry.title: Mid-Season Jolt: Sahara Heats Up, Playoff Races Tighten

link.title: Mid-Season Jolt: Sahara Heats Up, Playoff Races Tighten

entry.content:
Week in Review

The week kicked off on Monday at 8:00 PM with The Shockers delivering a convincing 7-3 victory over the Muffin Men. It was a clean game with no penalties, but The Shockers’ offense was anything but polite. Caden Bower was a force, racking up four goals and two assists. Muffin Men’s Charles Levy responded with two goals in the third, but the deficit was too steep.

Wednesday evening, under the eyes of referees Benwell and Kuchar, brought a pair of compelling contests. At 8:00 PM, top-ranked Don Cherry’s battled the Flat-Earthers to a hard-fought 5-5 tie. Don Cherry’s saw contributions from Nik Tsatsos and Koch Tsatsos, while Anthony Pennino netted two for the Flat-Earthers, including a crucial equalizer late in the third.

The late game at 10:00 PM saw the biggest upset and a penalty-laden affair as The Sahara bested 4 Lines 5-4.

The Sahara’s Kosta Likourezos bagged a hat-trick (3 goals, 2 assists) This offensive surge was pivotal for The Sahara, who gained two crucial points. 4 Lines’ Jamie Poole, a true productive agitator, scored a goal amidst two minor penalties for Unsportsmanlike Conduct and Interference. This win propels The Sahara into a tie with The Shockers at 17 points, just a hair behind the Muffin Men’s 16 points, making the middle of the pack exceptionally tight.

The Three Stars of the Week

  • 1st Star: Caden Bower (The Shockers) - 6 Points (4 Goals, 2 Assists). Bower’s four-goal performance powered The Shockers to a commanding win.
  • 2nd Star: Kosta Likourezos (The Sahara) - 5 Points (3 Goals, 2 Assists). His hat-trick was the driving force behind The Sahara’s pivotal victory.
  • 3rd Star: Jamie Poole (4 Lines) - 1 Goal, 4 PIM. A gritty effort, contributing on the scoresheet and leaving his mark on the physical Wednesday night cap.
entry.summary: The January chill outside St. Mikes Arena gave way to some fiery competition inside this week, with significant shifts in the Monday/Wednesday Low B standings.

entry.title: Cherry-Picking Points: Leaders Consolidate, Mid-Pack Scrambles

link.title: Cherry-Picking Points: Leaders Consolidate, Mid-Pack Scrambles

entry.content:
The Week That Was: Stability at the Top, Scramble in the Middle

Amidst brisk January nights at St. Mikes Arena, the DMHL’s Monday/Wednesday Low B division delivered its usual blend of grit and goals. The week’s action notably solidified Don Cherry’s hold on the top spot.

Don Cherry’s extended their reign, making short work of the Muffin Men in an 8-1 rout on Wednesday. Ryan Willms potted a hat-trick and two assists, showcasing Cherry’s league-best goal differential. The Muffin Men’s lone tally, a power play goal from Ryan Irwin, offered little solace in an outing solidifying their lower-tier status.

Monday delivered a tight 6-5 win for 4 Lines over The Shockers. Luke Gravett led the charge for 4 Lines with two goals and two assists, including a crucial shorthanded marker. The Shockers, despite two goals from Maxime Gagnon and a spirited effort, couldn’t close the gap. 4 Lines solidify third, while The Shockers hover precariously near the bottom.

Wednesday’s late 5-5 tie between Flat-Earthers and The Sahara proved a physical affair. Eight penalties were doled out by referees Darcy McNamee and Sonny Martinello, keeping the penalty boxes busy. The Sahara, led by Wes Martin’s two goals and an assist, clawed back to force the tie against a Flat-Earthers squad that saw five different goal-scorers, including Anthony Pennino and Reid Chessell.

Three Stars of the Week

1st Star: Ryan Willms, Don Cherry’s

3 Goals, 2 Assists in a dominant 8-1 victory. Willms’ clinical finishing drove his team’s offense.

2nd Star: Luke Gravett, 4 Lines

2 Goals, 2 Assists, including a shorthanded goal in a tight 6-5 win against The Shockers.

3rd Star: Wes Martin, The Sahara

2 Goals, 1 Assist. Martin’s offensive output was crucial in securing a 5-5 tie from a deficit.
entry.summary: Don Cherry's extends lead with a dominant performance, while 4 Lines nudge past The Shockers in a nail-biter.

entry.title: Sahara Blanks Cherry’s in Stunner, Shake Up M/W Low B Landscape

link.title: Sahara Blanks Cherry’s in Stunner, Shake Up M/W Low B Landscape

entry.content:
The Week That Was: A December Chill and Shifting Sands

Monday, December 22nd, brought a palpable chill to Toronto’s rinks, echoing some unexpected shifts in the Monday/Wednesday Low B standings. The Mattamy Athletic Centre saw some tight contests, but the biggest story unfolded later at the Upper Canada College School Arena, where The Sahara delivered a shockwave.

The Sahara, previously lurking at Rank 6, delivered a stunning 6-0 shutout against the league-leading Don Cherry’s. This wasn’t just a win; it was a statement.

The Sahara’s #14 Wes Martin potted a hat-trick, with goals spread across all three periods, setting the tone for their dominant performance. Their first goal came just 1:10 into the first period. This decisive victory vaulted The Sahara into a tie for 5th place with The Shockers, drastically improving their goal differential. Don Cherry’s, meanwhile, will be keen to erase this memory. The officiating crew of Mark Donohoe and John Hall kept the game flowing smoothly, with zero penalties called.

Earlier, at the Mattamy Athletic Centre, the Flat-Earthers edged out The Shockers 3-2 in a game riddled with penalties.

The Flat-Earthers were whistled for five minors, including two on #2 Anthony Pennino, while The Shockers had one. Despite the parade to the box, Flat-Earthers secured two points, with #5 Reid Chessell notching a goal and an assist. The Shockers’ #44 Nick Chong contributed two assists, but it wasn’t enough.

The Muffin Men and 4 Lines also clashed at Mattamy, with 4 Lines emerging victorious 6-5 in another closely contested match.

#10 Charles Levy of the Muffin Men put up 2 goals and an assist, showcasing his offensive prowess. However, 4 Lines’ balanced attack, led by #24 Ryan Fitzgerald’s 2 goals and an assist, secured them the win and solidified their hold on third place. #17 Adam Miller also chipped in with three assists for 4 Lines.

Three Stars of the Week

  • 1st Star: Wes Martin (The Sahara) - A commanding performance with 3 goals and 1 assist in the monumental shutout against Don Cherry’s.
  • 2nd Star: Charles Levy (Muffin Men) - Despite the loss, Levy was an offensive force, tallying 2 goals and 1 assist.
  • 3rd Star: Kosta Likourezos (The Sahara) - Crucial to The Sahara’s upset, with 1 goal and 2 assists, providing offensive punch and contributing to the clean sheet.
entry.summary: Week's action sees upsets and tight battles as division favorites get tested.

entry.title: Low B’s December Drama: Cherry Picking Points & Shifting Sands

link.title: Low B’s December Drama: Cherry Picking Points & Shifting Sands

entry.content:
The Week in Focus

Don Cherry’s solidified their top rank with a commanding win, extending their lead. The Muffin Men leveraged their matchup for crucial points, while the 4 Lines and Flat-Earthers’ deadlock kept the mid-table scramble heated. Official presence was varied, shaping game flows under Toronto’s chilly December skies.

Game Night Breakdown

Monday, December 15th, brought intense action. Don Cherry’s demolished The Shockers 6-1 at UCC Arena, with Ryan Willms (2G, 2A) and Koch Tsatsos (1G, 3A) leading the charge. Referees Mark Donohoe and Basil Jones were active, calling four Shockers penalties that effectively curtailed their offense.

Don Cherry’s: 6 goals, The Shockers: 1 goal.

At St. Mikes, the Muffin Men secured a 5-1 victory over The Sahara. Owen Burry (2G) and Cosimo Morin (2G) powered their decisive performance. The night’s most dramatic contest saw 4 Lines and the Flat-Earthers fight to a thrilling 4-4 tie. Jamie Poole (2G) netted for 4 Lines, but Anthony Pennino (2G, 1PPG) buried a crucial late powerplay equalizer for the Flat-Earthers. Referees John Hall and Shane Bowler handled multiple infractions across both St. Mikes games.

Muffin Men: 5 goals, The Sahara: 1 goal. 4 Lines: 4 goals, Flat-Earthers: 4 goals (1PPG).

Closing the week on a brisk Thursday, December 18th, 4 Lines took a 4-2 win over Pdiym at the Mattamy Athletic Centre, with Thomas Bevilacqua contributing. Referee Sonny Martinello maintained a notably hands-off approach, calling just one minor penalty all game, making for a remarkably free-flowing contest.

4 Lines: 4 goals. Pdiym: 2 goals.

The Three Stars

  • 1st Star: Michael Murphy (Don Cherry’s) – His league-leading 29 points (16G, 13A) underscored Don Cherry’s dominant offensive output.
  • 2nd Star: Charles Levy (Muffin Men) – A potent 27 points (17G, 10A) fueled the Muffin Men’s critical win.
  • 3rd Star: Anthony Pennino (Flat-Earthers) – With 23 points (13G, 10A) and a clutch powerplay goal, he salvaged a vital tie.
entry.summary: Division leaders pull ahead as middle-tier brawls, all under the watchful, yet inconsistent, eyes of the officials.

entry.title: December Duel: Sahara, Shockers Rise; Cherry’s Keeps Crown

link.title: December Duel: Sahara, Shockers Rise; Cherry’s Keeps Crown

entry.content:
Standings Jousting and Hot Streaks

The frosty grip of early December in Toronto brought a heated week of DMHL action. Don Cherry’s reaffirmed their top spot, while The Sahara and The Shockers made significant moves up the standings ladder.

This Week’s Action

Monday, December 1st (St. Mikes Arena): The Sahara edged out 4 Lines 6-4. Isaac Jeffers (1G, 2A) and Derrick Wong (1G, 2A, including a pivotal PP goal) orchestrated a third-period comeback. Sam Goldstein’s two goals sealed it, overcoming two shorthanded tallies from 4 Lines. Referees Carlos Verde and Mike Bonke had a busy night, calling five penalties in total.

Tuesday, December 2nd (UCC Arena): Don Cherry’s secured a 4-2 victory against the Flat-Earthers. Sean Murphy’s two goals, including a crucial shorthanded marker, proved the difference, solidifying Don Cherry’s league-leading

“Goals For: 85, GFA: 4.47.” The late 10:30 PM tilt saw minimal penalties, just three minors called.

Wednesday, December 3rd (St. Mikes Arena): The Shockers dominated the Muffin Men with a commanding 6-1 win. Caden Bower (1G, 1A) contributed to a four-goal second period, overwhelming the Muffin Men whose lone goal came late from Charles Levy. This victory propels The Shockers into a points tie with The Sahara, both now ahead of Muffin Men.

The Low B Dispatch Three Stars of the Week

1st Star: Isaac Jeffers (The Sahara) – 1 Goal, 2 Assists 2nd Star: Derrick Wong (The Sahara) – 1 Goal (PPG), 2 Assists 3rd Star: Sean Murphy (Don Cherry’s) – 2 Goals (1 SHG)
entry.summary: A week of decisive victories and clutch performances reshapes the Monday/Wednesday Low B landscape.

entry.title: **Muffin Men and Shockers Make Their Move; Don Cherry’s Stays Dominant**

link.title: **Muffin Men and Shockers Make Their Move; Don Cherry’s Stays Dominant**

entry.content:
Week in Review: Nov 24-26

The Monday/Wednesday Low B division saw some decisive swings this week, particularly impacting the middle of the standings. Don Cherry’s solidified their top spot, while Muffin Men and The Shockers clawed their way up.

Monday night at St. Mikes Arena, Don Cherry’s asserted their dominance with an 8-5 victory over 4 Lines. Koch Tsatsos led the charge with a hat-trick, supported by Michael Murphy and Ben Pirie, each netting a pair.

Don Cherry’s offense was firing on all cylinders with 8 goals, showcasing why they lead the league with a 0.763 Win Percentage.

4 Lines kept it competitive, with Ethan Lowe adding two goals, but couldn’t close the gap. Referees Mike Bonke and Russell Nichols oversaw a game with only one double minor penalty, indicating a relatively clean contest for such a high-scoring affair.

Wednesday saw a pair of games at St. Mikes. In the 9:00 PM slot, The Shockers delivered a resounding 7-1 win against The Sahara. Patrick Mcmullan and Alex Matheson each potted two goals, with Maxime Gagnon, Nick Chong, and Gabe Fischer-Schmidt also finding the back of the net.

The Shockers’ offensive outburst was a significant move, improving their goal differential to 0.

Later at 10:00 PM, The Muffin Men put on a clinic, humbling the Flat-Earthers with an 8-1 victory. Charles Levy was a force with two goals and two assists, while Ryan Irwin and Owen Burry each tallied a goal and two assists. Remarkably, this late-night tilt saw zero penalties called by referees Evan Benwell and Carlos Verde, a testament to pure, unadulterated hockey. The Flat-Earthers, despite strong individual talent, couldn’t find their footing.

“A truly unblemished scoresheet, aside from the obvious goal differential, is a rarity in Wednesday night hockey,” remarked one veteran scout.

The Three Stars of the Week

  • 1st Star: Koch Tsatsos (Don Cherry’s) – A hat-trick performance with 3 goals in his team’s commanding win.
  • 2nd Star: Charles Levy (Muffin Men) – Dominated with 2 goals and 2 assists, driving his team’s offensive explosion.
  • 3rd Star: Patrick Mcmullan (The Shockers) – Contributed 2 goals and 2 assists, fueling The Shockers’ decisive victory.
entry.summary: *Mid-week results shake up the bottom half, while the league leaders continue their steady pace.*
